questions.text: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of a productive cough and shortness of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and respirations are 32/min. Crackles are heard over the entire left lung fields. His leukocyte count is 17,400/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows a pulmonary infiltrate of the left lung. Sputum culture confirms infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae. A biopsy specimen from the pulmonary interstitium adjacent to the infiltrate is shown. Which of the following mediators is most likely responsible for the presence of the cell type indicated by the arrows?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin E is the main mediator of allergic responses by binding to Fc receptors found on the surface of mast cells and basophils, leading to the release and extravasation of eosinophils. However, the indicated cell is not an eosinophil, which is characterized by brick red cytoplasmic granules with eosin staining.

B) CORRECT:

Platelet activating factor (PAF) is involved in leukocyte extravasation by mediating WBC migration. In acute inflammation, as seen here, chemotactic factors, including PAF, complement component 5a (C5a), interleukin-8, leukotriene B4 (LTB4), and kallikrein are released in response to bacteria and attract neutrophils to the site of infection. N-formylmethionine (via LTB4) and endotoxin (via C5a) are also commonly implicated in neutrophil attraction.
Image Description:

Marginalization: The liver releases fibrinogen, an acute phase protein, in response to cytokines produced by macrophages, monocytes, and other cells (not shown). The increased levels of fibrinogen cause rouleaux formation (not shown), which pushes neutrophils towards the venule endothelium.

Rolling: Adhesion molecules on neutrophils (e.g., Sialyl-LewisX) and other leukocytes interact with adhesion molecules on endothelial cells (e.g., E-selectin, P-selectin), causing leukocytes to roll along the endothelial surface. Chemokines pass through the endothelium and then bind to proteoglycans in the intravascular lumen.

Adhesion: In response to cytokines, cellular adhesion molecules (e.g., ICAM) are upregulated on endothelial cells and integrins (e.g., β2-integrin) are upregulated on leukocytes, which bind firmly to endothelial cells via these cell adhesion molecules and integrins.

Diapedesis: Leukocytes cross the endothelial wall. Neutrophils release type IV collagenase to dissolve the basement membrane. Neutrophils and endothelial cells express platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1), which regulates diapedesis.

Migration: Leukocytes, mediated by chemoattractants, move to the site of infection through a process called chemotaxis. Chemoattractants that draw neutrophils to the site of infection include leukotrienes (e.g., LTB4), platelet-activating factor (PAF), chemokines (e.g., IL-8), kallikrein, complement fragments (e.g., C5a), and bacterial products.

C) INCORRECT:

Interferon gamma stimulates the proliferation of macrophages. However, the indicated cell in the image is not a macrophage, which would instead appear as a relatively large mononuclear cell with a kidney-bean-shaped nucleus and abundant cytoplasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-10 is an important anti-inflammatory signaling molecule. This molecule does not play a role in neutrophil extravasation during acute inflammation and does not become important until later in the progression of inflammation. Interleukin-8, in turn, is a neutrophil chemotactic agent.

E) INCORRECT:

Complement factor C3a is one of the most potent anaphylatoxins. Although it is strongly proinflammatory, it has not been implicated in neutrophil chemotaxis. Complement factor C5a, in turn, is a potent neutrophil chemotactic factor.
questions.hint: Segmented nuclei of various shapes are characteristic of neutrophils.

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of painful rash after spending several hours in the sun. Skin examination shows well-demarcated areas of erythema with some scaling on the face, chest, upper back, and arms. The affected areas are hot and sensitive to touch. The oral mucosa appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's skin findings?

choices.text: Vascular endothelial cell injury in the superficial dermis
Keratinocyte and fibroblast proliferation in the epidermis
Immune complex deposits at the dermoepidermal junction
Mast cell activation in the superficial dermis
Apoptosis of keratinocytes in the epidermis
T-cell-mediated inflammatory reaction in the dermis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema migrans, the dermatologic manifestation of stage I Lyme disease, is caused by injury to vascular endothelial cells in the superficial epidermis. Unlike this patient's rash, erythema migrans presents as a circular, slowly expanding, erythematous ring with a central clearing. The lesions are typically painless and accompanied by flu-like symptoms. Patients typically have a history of a recent hiking or camping trip, a tick bite, or travel to an endemic region of the US.

B) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of keratinocytes and fibroblasts in the epidermis is involved in the pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans. Lesions in acanthosis nigricans are velvety and hyperpigmented and typically occur in the axillae, groin, and neck. This dermatologic finding occurs most commonly in association with insulin resistance, although it can also represent a paraneoplastic syndrome. This patient's rash is well-circumscribed and erythematous, and she has no symptoms suggestive of insulin resistance or malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposition of immune complexes at the dermoepidermal junction is observed in the immunohistopathology of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The characteristic dermatologic finding of SLE is a malar rash which involves the nasal bridge and cheeks but spares the nasolabial folds. Patients with SLE can also develop oral ulcers. This patient has a well-demarcated rash in sun-exposed areas, and she does not have other symptoms of SLE including fevers, fatigue, myalgias, arthralgias, or lupus nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Mast cell activation and initiation of the inflammatory cascade in the superficial epidermis is involved in the pathogenesis of a type I hypersensitivity reaction. These reactions occur within minutes of exposure to an allergen. The characteristic dermatologic finding in type I hypersensitivity reactions is urticaria, which consists of pruritic, erythematous plaques. This patient's rash is only present in sun-exposed regions, she has no history of recent allergen contact, and she has no other symptoms of a type I hypersensitivity reaction, such as angioedema, bronchospasm, abdominal cramping, rhinitis, and pulmonary edema.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's rash following prolonged sun exposure is consistent with dermatitis solaris, or sunburn. Sunburn is caused by ultraviolet (primarily UVB) radiation-induced damage of the epidermis, which results in keratinocyte apoptosis and release of inflammatory mediators within the epidermis and dermis. Lesions are painful and erythematous and appear within hours of sun exposure. Sunburn is typically restricted to sun-exposed skin, as reflected by involvement of this patient's face, chest, upper back, and arms, and sparing of the oral mucosa.

F) INCORRECT:

Contact between an antigen and pre-sensitized T lymphocytes in the dermis initiates the inflammatory cascade in type IV hypersensitivity reactions. The characteristic dermatologic finding in type IV hypersensitivity reactions is a pruritic, erythematous, papular rash that can progress to oozing vesicles. The rash develops within 12–48 hours of repeat exposure to an antigen like nickel, latex, or poison ivy, and spreads to other parts of the body by physical contact. This patient has no history of exposure to an allergen, and her rash is inconsistent with type IV hypersensitivity.
questions.hint: UVB-radiation causes DNA-damage of epidermal cells.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Serum studies show:


Aspartate aminotransferase
134 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
152 U/L


γ-Glutamyltransferase
83 U/L (N = 5–50)


Hepatitis B surface antigen
positive


A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on liver biopsy is shown. These biopsy findings are most characteristic of which of the following types of inflammatory reactions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute hepatitis B would be positive for HBsAg and have findings of acute viral hepatitis (e.g., transaminitis, hepatocyte swelling). In acute viral hepatitis, however, the transaminitis would be severe (typically > 500 U/L), the hepatocytes would not have a uniformly hazy appearance (as seen here) and other histopathological findings such as eosinophilic apoptotic hepatocytes (Councilman body) would be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a hepatic tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

There is heavy necroinflammatory activity in this hepatic lobule. The hepatocytes show reactive changes, including prominent swelling (exemplary green outline). Several apoptotic hepatocytes (also known as “acidophilic bodies” or “Councilman bodies;” examples indicated by yellow outlines) are visible.

These findings are typical of inflammatory changes consistent with an acute viral hepatitis (in this case hepatitis B exacerbated by hepatitis E coinfection).

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic necrosis would appear on liver biopsy as necrotic hepatocytes in the centrilobular zone and result in acute hepatitis with severe transaminitis (typically > 1000 U/L). Mild transaminitis and liver biopsy findings indicate a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation (e.g., development of hepatocellular carcinoma) may occur as a consequence of hepatitis B infection, which this patient has. However, expected biopsy findings would include signs of nuclear atypia or dedifferentiation, which are not present here.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatic granulomas would appear as organized collections of activated macrophages (epithelioid histiocytes) on biopsy. This finding is most commonly seen in TB and schistosomiasis infections. This patient's biopsy, however, does not show any granulomas and serum findings are suggestive of viral hepatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Swollen and uniformly cloudy hepatocytes due to hyperplasia of the endoplasmic reticulum (ground glass hepatocytes), as seen here, are pathognomic for chronic hepatitis B infection. Patients with chronic hepatitis B would have serum transaminase concentrations that are normal (in inactive chronic hepatitis B) or only mildly increased (in active chronic hepatitis B). Other histopathological features of chronic viral hepatitis include lymphocyte infiltration, interface hepatitis in the periportal zone (piecemeal necrosis), and in advanced stages, periportal fibrosis. Chronic inflammation of any tissue typically shows mononuclear cell infiltration (e.g., lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages) and fibrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A chronic inflammatory infiltrate (blue overlay) consisting of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophilic granulocytes can be seen in the center of the image. The infiltrate is located at the interface of the portal tract and hepatic lobules (yellow overlay), which is referred to as “interface hepatitis.”

These features are typical of chronic hepatitis, in this case, hepatitis B. Chronic inflammation of any tissue typically shows mononuclear cell infiltration (e.g., lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages) and fibrosis may be present simultaneously as well (not present here).
questions.hint: Serum studies positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) indicate hepatitis B infection. The liver biopsy finding indicates that this patient would also be positive for IgG anti-hepatitis B core (anti-HBc) antibodies.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of lower abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. He has a history of constipation. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Abdominal examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 19,000/mm3. A CT scan of the abdomen shows segmental wall thickening of the descending colon with multiple diverticula and a 5.0-cm, low-attenuation pelvic lesion with air-fluid levels. CT-guided drainage of the fluid collection yields 250 mL of yellow-greenish fluid. Release of which of the following substances is most likely responsible for the formation of the drained lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal coagulase is an enzyme produced by Staphylococcus aureus. This enzyme helps speeds up the process of building a fibrinogen wall around an abscess by converting fibrinogen to fibrin. However, it is not responsible for abscess formation itself and does not account for the involvement of gram-negative bacteria. S. aureus is also rarely implicated in colonic infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Major basic protein is one of several cationic proteins associated with the eosinophil granule. This protein is cytotoxic to respiratory epithelium and is present in the sputum of individuals with asthma. It is also involved in host defense against helminths and parasites but does not play a role in suppurative inflammation or liquefactive necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

IFN-γ is a cell signaling protein that mediates macrophage activity and the expression of MHC molecules. IFN-γ does not play a role in purulent exudate formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid (LTA) is anchored in the cytoplasmic membrane of all gram-positive bacteria and extends to the outer cell wall. There, LTA acts as an antigen that induces TNF-α and IL-1. Although both of these are key signaling cytokines involved in abscess formation, this reaction does not require the release of LTA. In addition, LTA does not account for the involvement of gram-negative bacteria, which are very likely to be involved in colon-derived intra-abdominal abscesses.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactic acid is an endogenous non-toxic molecule and an energetic substrate of gluconeogenesis. Lactic acid levels may be elevated in coagulative necrosis due to a tissue hypoxia, but lactic acid does not play a role in purulent exudate formation.

F) INCORRECT:

IL-3 is a cytokine that supports the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic stem cells. It is not involved in suppurative inflammation or liquefactive necrosis.

Interleukin 1 and 6 are key cytokines involved in abscess formation.

G) INCORRECT:

Histamine is a vasoactive amine and inflammatory mediatory that is released during mast cell degranulation in response to primarily injury, pathogens, or allergens. It does not play a role in purulent exudate formation.

H) CORRECT:

Lysosomal enzymes released by neutrophils and macrophages are responsible for abscess formation. These enzymes dissolve dead cells and kill bacteria in an acute inflammatory process known as suppurative inflammation, which leads to liquefactive necrosis and abscess formation.
questions.hint: The constellation of constipation, lower quadrant pain, and segmental colonic wall thickening with multiple diverticula and surrounding fat stranding indicates acute diverticulitis. The diverticulitis is complicated by an intra-abdominal abscess (low-attenuation pelvic lesion with air-fluid levels) that likely involves gram-negative bacteria like Bacteroides and E. coli, the most dominant types in the colon. The pus in an abscess is due to the dissolution of dead tissue and its transformation into a viscous mass, which is characteristic of liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever, malaise, cough, and shortness of breath for 2 months. He has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss during the same period. He works at a flour mill and does not smoke cigarettes. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F) and pulse oximetry shows 95% on room air. Diffuse fine crackles are heard over both lung fields. A chest x-ray shows patchy reticulonodular infiltrates in the mid and apical lung fields bilaterally. A photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following cytokines have the greatest involvement in the pathogenesis of the lesion indicated by the arrow?

choices.text: Tumor necrosis factor alpha and interleukin-4
Transforming growth factor beta and interleukin-12

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor alpha is a proinflammatory cytokine secreted by activated macrophages. It plays an integral role in the migration of white blood cells to sites of infection and in granuloma formation. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) is primarily known as an anti-inflammatory factor that reduces the activity of Th1 lymphocytes and macrophages. Thus, IL-4 would inhibit rather than promote granuloma formation. In addition, IL-4 induces naive T cell differentiation into Th2 cells and enhances antibody class switching to IgG and IgE as part of the humoral immune response.

B) CORRECT:

Interferon gamma and interleukin-2 (IL-2) are proinflammatory cytokines secreted by T cells. These cytokines promote Th1 cell proliferation and activation of macrophages, thus inducing an immune response against targeted antigens. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis involves an exaggerated immune response (combined type 3 hypersensitivity and type 4 hypersensitivity reaction) to inhaled organic particles, which leads to the development of foreign body granulomas (typically noncaseating granulomas), as seen in this patient's biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a proinflammatory cytokine that is primarily involved in the induction of acute phase reactions. Moreover, it can activate macrophages and induce granuloma formation. However, interferon alpha, which is expressed by virus-infected and malignant cells, is primarily involved in immune defense against viral infection and plays no role in the formation of pulmonary granulomas.

D) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-4 (IL-4) and interleukin-10 (IL-10) are cytokines produced by Th2 cells. IL-4 and IL-10 function primarily as anti-inflammatory factors that reduce the activity of Th1 lymphocytes and macrophages. Thus, these cytokines would inhibit rather than promote granuloma formation. IL-4 induces naive T cell differentiation into Th2 cells and enhances antibody class switching to IgG and IgE as part of the humoral immune response.

E) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) plays an integral role in granuloma formation through the activation of antigen-specific lymphocytes. However, transforming growth factor beta is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that inhibits macrophages. This would antagonize rather than trigger the formation of granulomas.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms (fever, malaise, cough, dyspnea, and weight loss) and imaging findings (patchy reticulonodular infiltrates) of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. The lesion indicated by the arrow is a noncaseating granuloma.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with 5 days of progressively worsening right lower abdominal pain that initially began diffusely but became localized to the right iliac fossa. He reports intermittent fever, chills, and anorexia. Palpation of the right lower quadrant elicits marked tenderness and involuntary guarding (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
105/min


Blood pressure
118/75 mmHg


Temperature
38.7°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
16 × 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Neutrophils
85%
40 - 60%



Ultrasound: Fluid collection in the right iliac fossa consistent with an abscess forming around an inflamed appendix
Which mechanism best explains the increased blood flow in this inflamed area?

choices.text: Local release of vasoactive mediators causing arteriolar dilation
Neural reflexes triggering mesenteric vessel constriction
Mechanical compression of local vessels by the abscess
Bacterial endotoxins leading to localized vasospasm

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In inflammation, injured tissues and resident immune cells release vasoactive substances such as histamine, prostaglandins, and bradykinin. These mediators cause relaxation of smooth muscle surrounding arterioles, leading to vasodilation. This process, known as hyperemia, increases blood flow to the affected area, facilitating the delivery of immune cells, nutrients, and oxygen, which support tissue defense and repair mechanisms.

Key learning point: In appendicular abscess, a complication of appendicitis, the body exhibits redistribution of blood flow as a pathophysiological response to inflammation and infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased blood flow in acute inflammation is mediated by local chemical factors, not neural reflexes. Inflammatory mediators such as histamine and prostaglandins cause vasodilation, increasing blood flow. Neural reflexes causing vessel constriction would reduce blood flow, contrary to the hyperemic response in inflammation.

C) INCORRECT:

Mechanical compression by an abscess would reduce blood flow by narrowing vessel lumens. In contrast, increased blood flow in inflammation is due to vasodilation from mediators like histamine and nitric oxide, which enhance perfusion and support the inflammatory response.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial endotoxins, components of Gram-negative bacteria, can trigger systemic inflammatory responses but do not cause localized vasospasm. Inflammation-induced hyperemia results from the release of mediators like histamine and nitric oxide, which cause arteriolar dilation and increased blood flow, not vasospasm.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-year-history of cough and progressively worsening breathlessness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Physical examination shows contraction of the anterior scalene and sternocleidomastoid muscles during inspiration. An x-ray of the chest shows flattening of the diaphragm and increased radiolucency in the lower lung fields. Further analysis shows increased activity of an isoform of elastase that is normally inhibited by alpha-1-antitrypsin. The cells that produce this isoform of elastase were most likely stimulated to enter the site of inflammation by which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HMWK is a circulating plasma protein that is the precursor of the vasodilator bradykinin. During tissue injury, HMWK is activated by kallikrein, leading to an increase in vascular permeability, which facilitates cell migration to the site of injury. While kallikrein is a potent neutrophil chemotactic agent, HMWK is not known to act as a neutrophil chemokine and would not have played a role in the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of inflammation in this patient's lungs.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactoferrin is a glycoprotein component of the innate immune system. It binds free iron with high affinity, thus limiting the amount of ions available for microbial metabolism. It also acts as an antimicrobial agent by hydrolyzing RNA of foreign bodies. It is stored in neutrophil granules and is released as an acute phase reactant. However, lactoferrin does not function as a neutrophil chemotactic agent and would not have played a role in the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of inflammation in this patient's lungs.

C) INCORRECT:

IFN-γ is a cytokine involved in both innate and adaptive immune responses. Activation of macrophages increases the production of macrophage elastases, which damage the parenchymal structure of the lungs, leading to emphysema. However, macrophage elastases are inactivated by tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs), not α1-antitrypsin, which inactivates neutrophil elastases.

D) INCORRECT:

Nitric oxide (NO) is a gaseous free radical produced in some cells as a signaling molecule (produced by NO synthase) or as part of the immune response. Once activated, neutrophils secrete NO in an attempt to kill pathogens with the free radical. However, NO is not known to possess neutrophil chemotactic properties and would not have played a role in the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of inflammation in this patient's lungs.

E) INCORRECT:

C4a is a product of the complement pathways. The function of the molecule is not well understood, though it is thought to induce calcium mobilization in cells. While C4a is structurally similar to the potent neutrophil chemotactic factor C5a, C4a is not known to possess neutrophil chemotactic properties and would not have played a role in the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of inflammation in this patient's lungs.

F) CORRECT:

Leukotriene B4, along with IL-8, kallikrein, C5a, and platelet-activating factor are all neutrophilic chemotactic agents. Recruitment and activation of neutrophils in the lungs lead to an increase in elastase production and damage to the parenchymal tissue. In cases of AATD, the unopposed enzymatic activity of the proteases destroys the architecture of whole pulmonary acini, leading to panacinar emphysema.

G) INCORRECT:

TXA2 is an arachidonic acid derivative produced by activated platelets. It plays an important role during tissue injury and inflammation as a potent vasoconstrictor. However, TXA2 is not a known neutrophil chemokine and would not have played a role in the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of inflammation in this patient's lungs.
questions.hint: Early-onset emphysema that predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung is characteristic of alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (AATD). Alpha-1-antitrypsin inactivates the neutrophilic isoform of elastase, which is stored in the azurophil granules.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling of her left foot. Three days ago, she cut her foot on an exposed rock at the beach. Her temperature is 37.7°C (100°F). Examination of the left foot shows edema around a fluctuant erythematous lesion on the lateral foot. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism for the development of edema in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Direct production of fluid by bacteria may cause local edema. Bacillus anthracis, for instance, is known to produce edema toxin, which is responsible for the characteristically edematous wounds seen in cutaneous anthrax. However, this patient does not have the classic black eschar (painless, pruritic skin lesion forming an ulcer with a surrounding edema and a central necrotic area), making cutaneous anthrax unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure causes secretion of fluid into the interstitium, thereby forming edema. However, this is a form of generalized edema seen in heart failure and other hypervolemic states, not localized edema as in this patient. The volume-expanded state of many patients with heart failure produces venous hypertension, and as a result, capillary and venous pressure overcome the tissue oncotic pressure. The exact degree of edema that results in these situations is governed by the Starling equation.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased plasma oncotic pressure is responsible for edema that develops in patients with hypoalbuminemia (e.g., cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, or malnourishment). Loss of intravascular protein leads to fluid extravasation (as governed by Starling forces). However, this would cause a generalized form of edema (e.g., bilateral pedal edema), not an acute localized edema as in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic cytokine release is an important factor of edema formation in burned patients. The overwhelming inflammatory response, mediated by proinflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor α (TNF-α) and interleukin 6 (IL-6), greatly enhances fluid extravasation into tissues. However, this would cause generalized edema, not a localized process in the foot after direct tissue trauma as in this patient. Also, systemic inflammation and cytokine release would be unlikely in the absence of constitutional signs/symptoms (e.g., high fever, tachycardia, or hypotension).

E) CORRECT:

The acute inflammatory reaction occurring in this patient's foot is prompting localized mast cell degranulation and increased histamine concentration surrounding the wound. Histamine causes separation of endothelial junctions, breaking apart endothelial cells of the microvasculature (venules), thereby increasing vascular permeability and paracellular movement of fluid, which clinically manifests as local edema.
questions.hint: Edema is an accumulation of fluid in certain tissues like the skin.
